'''Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds''' are an Australian [[rock music|rock]] band formed in 1983 by vocalist [[Nick Cave]], multi-instrumentalist [[Mick Harvey]] and guitarist-vocalist [[Blixa Bargeld]]. The band has featured international personnel throughout its career and presently consists of Cave, violinist and multi-instrumentalist [[Warren Ellis (musician)|Warren Ellis]], bassist [[Martyn P. Casey]] (all from Australia), guitarist [[George Vjestica]] (United Kingdom), keyboardist/percussionist Toby Dammit (United States) and drummers [[Thomas Wydler]] (Switzerland) and [[Jim Sclavunos]] (United States). Described as "one of the most original and celebrated bands of the [[post-punk]] and [[alternative rock]] eras in the '80s and onward",<ref name="AMbio" /> they have released seventeen studio albums and completed numerous international tours.

The band was founded following the demise of Cave and Harvey's former group [[The Birthday Party (band)|the Birthday Party]], the members of which met at a boarding school in [[Melbourne]].<ref name="Simon" /> Throughout the 1980s, beginning with their debut LP ''[[From Her to Eternity]]'' (1984), the band drew largely on post-punk, [[blues]] and [[gothic rock]], and brought in musicians such as [[Blixa Bargeld]], [[Barry Adamson]] and [[Kid Congo Powers]]. The band later softened their sound and incorporated other influences on albums such as ''[[The Good Son (album)|The Good Son]]'' (1990) and ''[[The Boatman's Call]]'' (1997). Following Harvey's departure in 2009,<ref name="Mick" /> the band broadened their sound further to include electronic and ambient styles, which feature prominently on the trilogy of albums ''[[Push the Sky Away]]'' (2013), ''[[Skeleton Tree]]'' (2016) and ''[[Ghosteen]]'' (2019).

==History==
===Formation and early releases (1983–1985)===
The project that later evolved into Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds began following the demise of [[the Birthday Party (band)|The Birthday Party]] in August 1983. Both Cave and Harvey were members of the Birthday Party, along with guitarist [[Rowland S. Howard]] and bassist [[Tracy Pew]]. During the recording sessions of the Birthday Party's scheduled EPs ''[[Mutiny/The Bad Seed]]'', internal disputes developed in the band. The difference in Cave and Howard's approach to songwriting was a major factor, as Cave explained in an interview with ''On The Street'': "the main reason why The Birthday Party broke up was that the sort of songs that I was writing and the sort of songs that Rowland was writing were just totally at odds with each other." Following the departure of Harvey, they officially disbanded. Cave also said that "it probably would have gone on longer, but Mick has the ability to judge things much more clearly than the rest of us."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cave|first1=Nick|last2=Miller|first2=Rob|year=1984|title=''In a Black Box with Nick Cave''|journal=On the Street|issue=May 1984|url=http://www.bad-seed.org/~cave/interviews/83-05_ots.html|access-date=14 February 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Nick Cave 1986.jpg|thumb|150px|Cave and guitarist [[Kid Congo Powers]] during the band's 1986 tour.]]

An embryonic version of what became Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds was formed in the Birthday Party's then-home of London in September 1983, with Cave, Harvey (acting primarily as drummer), [[Einstürzende Neubauten]] guitarist Blixa Bargeld, [[Magazine (band)|Magazine]] bassist [[Barry Adamson]], and [[Jim G. Thirlwell]]. The band was initially formed as a backing band for Cave's intended solo project ''Man or Myth?'', which had been approved by the record label [[Mute Records]]. During September and October 1983, they recorded material with producer [[Flood (producer)|Flood]],<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=''From Her to Eternity''|title-link=From Her to Eternity|others=Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds|year=1984|type=CD|publisher=Mute Records|id=5099923724228}}</ref> although the sessions were cut short due to Cave's touring with [[the Immaculate Consumptive]], another project formed with Thirlwell, [[Lydia Lunch]] and [[Marc Almond]].<ref>{{cite book|title=''Alternative Rock: Third Ear - The Essential Listening Companion''|last=Thompson|first=Dave|author-link=Dave Thompson (author)|year=2000 |publisher=Miller Freeman|isbn=0-87930-607-6|page=425}}</ref> In December 1983 Cave returned to [[Melbourne, Australia]], where he formed a temporary line-up of his backing band, due to Bargeld's absence, that included Pew and guitarist [[Hugo Race]]. The band performed their first live show at Seaview in [[St. Kilda, Victoria|St. Kilda]] on 31 December 1983.<ref name="fta">{{cite web|title=From The Archives - Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds- Concert Chronology / Gigography|url=http://www.fromthearchives.com/nc/chronology.html|work=From the Archives|access-date=27 August 2010}}</ref>

Following a short Australian tour, and during a period when they were without management, Cave and his band returned to London. Cave, Harvey, Bargeld, Race and Adamson formed the project's first consistent line-up, while Cave's longtime girlfriend [[Anita Lane]] was credited as a lyricist on occasional songs (e.g., the title track of 1984's ''[[From Her to Eternity]]''). The group, which up to this time had been nameless, adopted the moniker Nick Cave and the Cavemen, which they used for the first six months of their career. However, they were later renamed Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds in May 1984, in reference to the final Birthday Party EP ''The Bad Seed''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} They began recording sessions for their debut album in March 1984 at London's [[Trident Studios]] and these sessions, together with the abandoned ''Man or Myth?'' sessions from September–October 1983 that were recorded at The Garden studios, formed the album ''From Her to Eternity'', released on Mute Records in 1984. Thirlwell left during the recording sessions for ''Eternity'', citing creative disagreements and desires to work on his own solo material.<ref name=Wray2014>Daniel Dylan Wray (2014) [http://thequietus.com/articles/16018-the-birthday-party-interview-nick-cave-and-the-bad-seeds If This Is Heaven I'm Bailing Out: The Death Of The Birthday Party ], The Quietus, accessed 5 Jan 2017</ref> Race, and touring guitarist Edward Clayton-Jones, left to form [[the Wreckery]] in Melbourne.<ref name="McFarlane tW">{{cite book | last1 = McFarlane | first1 = Ian | author-link1 = Ian McFarlane | title = [[Encyclopedia of Australian Rock and Pop]] | chapter = Encyclopedia entry for 'The Wreckery' | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20040803170443/http://www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=793 | chapter-url = http://www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=793 | year = 1999 | publisher = [[Allen & Unwin]] | location = [[St Leonards, New South Wales|St Leonards, NSW]] | archive-date = 3 August 2004 | isbn = 1-86508-072-1 }}</ref>

===Move to Germany and stylistic evolution (1985–1989)===
After the departure of Race and Lane, the remaining members moved to West Berlin, Germany in 1985 and released a second album ''[[The Firstborn Is Dead]]''. The album was heavily influenced by the gothic [[Americana (music)|Americana]] of the [[American South]] and [[blues music]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/r3471|title=''The Firstborn is Dead'' - Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds|website=[[AllMusic]]|date=6 January 2012}}</ref> exemplified in songs such as "[[Tupelo (Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds song)|Tupelo]]" and "Blind Lemon Jefferson", which reference the birth of [[Elvis Presley]] and [[Blind Lemon Jefferson]] respectively. Released the following year, the album ''[[Kicking Against the Pricks]]'' explored such influences with renditions of material by [[Johnny Cash]], [[John Lee Hooker]] and [[Lead Belly]]. The 1986 album also marked the arrival of Swiss drummer [[Thomas Wydler]], a member of [[Die Haut]], and featured guest appearances from Race, Pew, and Birthday Party guitarist Howard, who had briefly toured with the Bad Seeds as a substitute member in 1985.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} Pew's death from an epileptic seizure also occurred in 1986.<ref name="Simon" />

The band garnered an increased following due to a second 1986 album release, ''[[Your Funeral, My Trial]]'', which coincided with Adamson's departure.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} ''[[Tender Prey]]'', the dark, brooding<ref name=gs>{{cite web|url=http://drownedinsound.com/releases/15279/reviews/4139649|title=Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds - ''The Good Son'' review|publisher=Drowned in Sound|date=6 January 2012|access-date=7 January 2012|archive-date=31 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130331201116/http://drownedinsound.com/releases/15279/reviews/4139649|url-status=dead}}</ref> 1988 follow-up, saw the arrival of American guitarist and [[The Gun Club]] stalwart [[Kid Congo Powers]]—Harvey made the transition to bass—and short-tenured German keyboardist [[Roland Wolf (musician)|Roland Wolf]]. The single "[[The Mercy Seat (song)|The Mercy Seat]]" chronicled an unrepentant prisoner on [[death row]]<ref name="Simon" /> and further increased the group's critical acclaim and commercial attention. The track was later covered by Johnny Cash on his 2000 album ''[[American III: Solitary Man]]''. Despite the increasing level of success, the drug-related issues of band members became problematic.<ref name=gs /> The documentary film ''The Road to God Knows Where'', directed by [[Uli M Schueppel]], depicts a five-week period<ref>{{cite web|title=The Road to God knows where|url=http://www.schueppel-films.de/filmsy_en/the-road-to-god-knows-where|work=Uli M Schueppel|publisher=Uli M Schueppel|access-date=1 April 2013|year=2013}}</ref> of the United States leg of their 1989 tour.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Road to God Knows Where (1990)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100501/|work=IMDb|publisher=IMDb, Inc|access-date=1 April 2013|year=1990–2013}}</ref>

Cave and his bandmates also pursued other creative ambitions around this time. In 1987, the Bad Seeds appeared in the [[Wim Wenders]] film ''[[Wings of Desire]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m1uVDZ9Gpcg|work=YouTube|publisher=Google, Inc|access-date=1 April 2013|author=esadofe|format=Video upload|date=2 March 2008}}</ref> and Cave was featured in the 1988 film ''[[Ghosts... of the Civil Dead]]'', which he and Race co-wrote.<ref name="Dick">{{cite web|title='GHOSTS… OF THE CIVIL DEAD': NICK CAVE'S PSYCHOTIC CAMEO IN HARROWING 1989 AUSSIE PRISON DRAMA|url=http://dangerousminds.net/comments/ghosts_of_the_civil_dead_nick_caves_psychotic_cameo|work=Dangerous Minds|publisher=Dangerous Minds|access-date=1 April 2013|author=Richard Metzger|date=12 February 2013}}</ref> Cave's first novel ''[[And the Ass Saw the Angel]]'' was published in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|title=Book Review And the Ass Saw the Angel|url=http://www.themodernword.com/reviews/cave_angel.html|work=The Modern Word|publisher=The Modern Word|access-date=1 April 2013|author=LJ Lindhurst|date=13 August 2003|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130119074720/http://themodernword.com/reviews/cave_angel.html|archive-date=19 January 2013}}</ref>

===Growing success (1989–1997)===
After a period of time in New York City, Cave relocated to São Paulo, Brazil,<ref name="Simon">{{cite news|title=Old Nick|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/feb/23/popandrock.features|access-date=1 April 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=23 February 2008|author=Simon Hattenstone}}</ref> shortly after the final tour for ''Tender Prey'' and, after successfully finishing drug rehabilitation,<ref name=gs /> began experimenting with piano-driven ballads. The result of this post-rehabilitation period was 1990's ''[[The Good Son (album)|The Good Son]]''. Featuring a sorrowful and longing tone, the album was well-received both critically and commercially,<ref name=gs /> and yielded the singles "[[The Weeping Song]]" (featuring vocals from Bargeld) and "[[The Ship Song]]".{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}

Two established Australian musicians, Casey of [[the Triffids]] and solo artist and keyboardist Savage, replaced the departing Powers and Wolf. The addition of Casey on bass allowed Harvey to return to guitar. Their next record, 1992's ''[[Henry's Dream]]'', marked a change towards a harder rock sound. Producer [[David Briggs (record producer)|David Briggs]], known for his work with [[Neil Young]], was enlisted for the recording process. The tour for the album is documented on 1993's live album ''[[Live Seeds]]'' and showcases the new group's aggressive sound.
[[File:Interview Nick Cave by Che - 1993.webm|thumb|Cave discussing touring, what music means to him, and tensions in the band, 1993]]
In mid-1993, the group returned once more to London and recorded ''[[Let Love In (Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds album)|Let Love In]]'', the follow-up album. ''Let Love In'' expanded upon the fuller ensemble sound that was established in ''Henry's Dream''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sputnikmusic.com/review/28989/Nick-Cave-and-The-Bad-Seeds-Let-Love-In/|title=Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds - ''Let Love In'' review|website=Sputnik Music|date=6 January 2006}}</ref> and featured contributions from Howard, Ellis, [[Tex Perkins]] ([[Beasts of Bourbon]]) and [[David McComb]] (The Triffids).{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} Several popular songs, such as "[[Red Right Hand]]" (which featured in the ''[[Scream (film series)|Scream]]'' film series<ref>{{cite web|title=SCREAM 3 Movie Soundtrack- Red Right Hand (Scream 3 Version)- 52|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SAx5LVEzlGY|work=YouTube|publisher=Google, Inc|access-date=1 April 2013|date=4 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SCREAM 2 Movie Soundtrack- Red Right Hand (V2)- 22|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jd0MByffpt0|work=YouTube|publisher=Google, Inc|access-date=1 April 2013|date=12 August 2010}}</ref> and was used as the theme song for [[Peaky Blinders (TV series)|Peaky Blinders]]) and "[[Loverman]]" (later covered by [[Metallica]]),<ref>{{cite web|title=Metallica - Loverman (Nick Cave Cover)|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zvlzWPHWb0M|work=YouTube|publisher=Google, Inc|access-date=1 April 2013|format=Video upload|date=29 November 2010}}</ref> were drawn from the album. During the promotional tour for the album, American percussionist and drummer [[Jim Sclavunos]] joined the group.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}}

In 1996 the band released ''[[Murder Ballads]]'', their best-selling album to date.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/78737/nick-cave-the-bad-seeds-return-with-new-look-at-old-themes|title=Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds Return With New Look at Old Themes|website=billboard.com|date=6 April 2001|access-date=24 March 2018}}</ref> Centered on the subject of murder, the album includes a cover of the folk song "Henry Lee"—a duet with British rock singer [[PJ Harvey]], with whom Cave had a brief relationship—<ref name="Simon" /> and "[[Where the Wild Roses Grow]]", a duet with Australian pop idol [[Kylie Minogue]]. The Minogue collaboration was a mainstream hit in the UK and Australia, and won three [[ARIA Awards|Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) Awards]], including Song of the Year. It was at this time that Ellis of the [[Dirty Three]] began regularly working with the band and eventually became Cave's primary collaborator.<ref name="Simon" />

The sound of ''[[The Boatman's Call]]'', released in 1997, was a radical departure from the archetypal and violent narratives of the band's past, featuring songs about relationships, loss, and longing, often with sparse arrangements. Cave revealed his mindset during the creation of the album in a 2008 interview: "When I was making half that record I was furious because certain things had happened in my love life that seriously pissed me off. And some of those songs came straight out of that. I don't regret making it ... the songs are of a moment when you felt a certain way. When ... you just think, 'Fuck - please!'"<ref name="Simon" /> The album's corresponding tour was later documented on the 2008 live album ''[[Live at the Royal Albert Hall (Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds album)|Live at the Royal Albert Hall]]''. After the release of the album, Cave embarked on a brief hiatus, during which time he remarried.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}}

===Further musical refinement; Bargeld's departure (1997–2005)===
[[File:Blixa Bargeld.jpg|alt=Blixa Bargeld|left|thumb|150px|Founding guitarist Bargeld left the band in 2003]]
Following Cave's hiatus the band oversaw the release of ''[[Original Seeds]]'', a compilation of material from other artists that influenced the group, as well as their own "best of" album ''[[The Best of Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds]]''. The proper follow-up to ''The Boatman's Call'' was 2001's ''[[No More Shall We Part]]''. The record featured guest appearances by [[Kate & Anna McGarrigle]] and was generally well received in reviews: one critic hailed the album as an "entire album of deeply tragic and beautiful love songs without irony, sarcasm, or violent resolution", while also stating that the work is at risk of devolving "into schmaltz".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/no-more-shall-we-part-r525864/review|title=''No More Shall We Part'' - Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds|publisher=All Music|date=6 January 2012}}</ref>

The band then released ''[[Nocturama (album)|Nocturama]]'' in 2003. The album marked a return to band-oriented and collaborative arrangements, as previous releases involved a decreased level of input from Cave's bandmates. ''Nocturama'' garnered mixed reviews, with critic Eric Carr stating that "in truth, it may still be the group's best work since ''Let Love In'', but it had the potential to be so much more".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/1366-nocturama-with-the-bad-seeds/|title=Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds: ''Nocturama''|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|date=6 January 2012}}</ref> Shortly after the album's release, Bargeld left the band after 20 years to devote more time to Einstürzende Neubauten.<ref>{{cite news|title=Blixa Bargeld to leave Bad Seeds|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2003/0303/caven.html|access-date=1 April 2013|newspaper=RTÉ|date=3 March 2003|agency=RTÉ Commercial Enterprises Ltd}}</ref>

In 2004 the band released the acclaimed two-disc set ''[[Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus]]'', with Bargeld replaced by the English actor, guitarist and organist [[James Johnston (English musician)|James Johnston]], a member of [[Gallon Drunk]] and former guest member of the Bad Seeds from a [[Lollapalooza]] tour ten years prior (Johnston only played organs on the recordings, as Harvey contributed the guitar pieces).<ref>{{cite web|title=Working With Ken Russell: Actor & Musician James Johnston Remembers|url=http://thequietus.com/articles/07501-ken-russell-obituary|work=The Quiteus|publisher=The Quiteus|access-date=1 April 2013|author=James Johnston}}</ref> Conceived as two separate albums packaged together, the record featured a diversity of arrangement styles, including aggressive rock and choir-driven ballads. In 2005 the band released ''[[B-Sides & Rarities (Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds album)|B-Sides & Rarities]]'', a three-volume, 56-song collection of [[B-side]]s, rarities and compilation tracks that was released on Mute Records in Europe, the US and the UK.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} ''[[The Abattoir Blues Tour]]'', a two-CD, two-DVD box set with performances from the album's promotional tour, was then released in 2007 in Europe and the US. The tour included guest [[backing vocalist]]s Ase Bergstrom, Geo Onaymake, Eleanor Palmer and Wendi Rose.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}

Also in 2005, Cave completed work on his script for ''[[The Proposition (2005 film)|The Proposition]]'', set in 19th-century Australia directed by [[John Hillcoat]].<ref name="Dick" /><ref>{{cite web|title=The Proposition|url=http://www.abc.net.au/atthemovies/txt/s1474241.htm|work=At The Movies|publisher=ABC|access-date=1 April 2013|author=Margaret Pomerantz|date=5 October 2005}}</ref> Cave and Ellis collaborated on the film's score,<ref>{{cite web|title=Gun Thing (The Proposition) - Nick Cave, Warren Ellis|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MieT8cNeXJA|work=YouTube|publisher=Google, Inc|access-date=1 April 2013|author=Gladiator33111|format=Video upload|date=1 October 2011}}</ref> a partnership that later also scored the films ''[[The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford]]'' (2007) and ''[[The Road (2009 film)|The Road]]'' (2009).<ref name="Simon" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Nick Cave and Warren Ellis The Road Review|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/r25c|work=BBC Music|publisher=BBC|access-date=1 April 2013|date=4 January 2010}}</ref>

===Grinderman; Harvey's departure (2006–2012)===
After operating for several years as a touring backing band for Cave's solo work, Bad Seeds members Ellis, Sclavunos and Casey formed a new side-project [[Grinderman]] with Cave in 2006. The band, featuring Cave playing guitar for the first time, played [[garage rock]]-influenced music that still retained much of The Bad Seeds' aura and released a [[Grinderman (album)|self-titled debut album]] in 2007.<ref name="Sean">{{cite news|title=Nick Cave: Grinderman are 'over'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/dec/12/nick-cave-grinderman|access-date=1 April 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=12 December 2011|author=Sean Michaels}}</ref> In October 2007 Cave was inducted into the [[ARIA Hall of Fame]] and, in his acceptance speech, also inducted the members of The Bad Seeds and The Birthday Party, after explaining, "I cannot really accept this until we get a few things straight. What I can't figure out is why I am up here and The Bad Seeds aren't?"<ref>{{cite news|title=Cave enters Aria Hall of Fame on his own terms|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/bmusicb-cave-enters-aria-hall-of-fame-on-his-own-terms/2007/10/28/1193555537649.html|access-date=1 April 2013|newspaper=The Age|date=29 October 2007}}</ref>

[[File:Grinderman.jpg|alt=Grinderman|thumb|right|Grinderman marked a return to a raw sound, as well as Cave's debut on guitar.]]

Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds released their 14th studio album ''[[Dig, Lazarus, Dig!!!]]'' in 2008 and received a high level of critical acclaim.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} Inspired by the biblical story of [[Lazarus of Bethany]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Nick Cave Digs Himself a Singular Niche|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=89947780|work=NPR Music|publisher=NPR|access-date=1 April 2013|format=Audio upload|date=25 April 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.www.buchtelite.com/media/storage/paper1203/news/2008/04/17/ArtsLife/Nick-Cave.And.The.Bad.Seeds.Release.dig.Lazarus.Dig-3329615.shtml|title=Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds release ''Dig, Lazarus, Dig!!!''|date=9 January 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://archive.today/20110708102909/http://media.www.buchtelite.com/media/storage/paper1203/news/2008/04/17/ArtsLife/Nick-Cave.And.The.Bad.Seeds.Release.dig.Lazarus.Dig-3329615.shtml|archive-date=8 July 2011}}</ref> the album continued the punk and garage rock-inspired arrangements that were explored on the debut Grinderman album, resulting in what ''[[NME]]'' termed a "[[gothic rock|gothic]] psycho-sexual apocalypse".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/nick-cave-and-the-bad-seeds/9484 |title= Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds Dig!!! Lazarus Dig!!! (album review) |work=NME |date=21 February 2008 |access-date=2 February 2012}}</ref> The group then embarked on a North American and European tour is support of the album, with a seven-piece lineup that did not include Johnston, who had left the group after the album's completion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forums.nickcaveandthebadseeds.com/viewtopic.php?t=22733 |title=View topic - James Johnston |publisher=Forums.nickcaveandthebadseeds.com |access-date=2011-07-05 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714181453/http://forums.nickcaveandthebadseeds.com/viewtopic.php?t=22733 |archive-date=14 July 2011 }}</ref>
[[File:Nick Cave - Q And A - Dublin,Ireland 2009.webm|thumb|The band talking to the crowd at a 2009 show]]
Cave and the band curated Australia's first edition of the [[All Tomorrow's Parties (music festival)|All Tomorrow's Parties]] music festival that was held in various Australian locations during January 2009. On 22 January, after the festival's completion, Harvey announced his departure from the band after 25 years, citing "a variety of personal and professional reasons". Harvey concluded his public statement by stating, "I shall continue working on the Bad Seeds back catalogue re-issues project over the coming year and look forward to the new opportunities I shall be able to accommodate as a result of my changed circumstances."<ref name="Mick">{{cite news|title=Bad Seeds co-founder Harvey quits|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2009-01-22/bad-seeds-co-founder-harvey-quits/2600690?section=entertainment|access-date=1 April 2013|newspaper=ABC News|date=23 January 2009}}</ref> Harvey's departure was the end of a 36-year-long musical collaboration between Cave and Harvey, and Cave was left as the group's only original member.<ref name="Sean" /> The band enlisted guitarist [[Ed Kuepper]], formerly of the Australian bands [[The Saints (Australian band)|the Saints]] and the [[Laughing Clowns]], as a touring member to complete the 2009 summer festival dates that were scheduled.<ref name="Ed">{{cite web|title=Interview: Ed Kuepper|url=http://www.emusic.com/music-news/music-collection/interview-ed-kuepper-2/|work=eMusic|publisher=Rovi Corporation|access-date=1 April 2013|date=18 February 2013}}</ref> Also in 2009, Cave published his second novel ''[[The Death of Bunny Munro]]'',<ref>{{cite news|title=The Death of Bunny Munro by Nick Cave|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/sep/13/death-bunny-munro-nick-cave|access-date=1 April 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=13 September 2009|author=Sean O'Hagan}}</ref> and Mute Records commenced work on a series of remastered versions of the Bad Seeds' back catalogue (some of the remastered albums included documentary footage from [[Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard]]).{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}

Following this string of activity, the Bad Seeds became dormant while Grinderman reactivated and released ''[[Grinderman 2]]'' in 2010.<ref name="Sean" /> The group also attracted further attention when their song "O Children" appeared in the 2010 film ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1]]''. In December 2011, Grinderman disbanded immediately following an Australian tour. Their final performance was at the [[Meredith Music Festival]] in rural Victoria.<ref name="Sean" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thevine.com.au/music/news/nick-cave-announces-that-grinderman-are-%27over%2720111211.aspx|title=Nick Cave announces that Grinderman are "over"|publisher=The Vine|date=7 January 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108053305/http://www.thevine.com.au/music/news/nick-cave-announces-that-grinderman-are-%27over%2720111211.aspx|archive-date=8 January 2012}}</ref>

===''Push the Sky Away'', ''Skeleton Tree'' and ''Ghosteen'' (2013–present)===
Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds' 15th studio album ''[[Push the Sky Away]]'' was released in mid-February 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/48724-nick-cave-and-the-bad-seeds-announce-new-album-push-the-sky-away/|title=Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds Announce New Album, ''Push the Sky Away'' | News|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|last=Snapes|first=Laura|date=27 November 2012|access-date=27 November 2012}}</ref> During the album's recording, former member Barry Adamson rejoined the band as a bassist, then assumed a multi-instrumentalist (percussion, keyboards, vocals) role on subsequent tours. Kuepper briefly returned as the band's touring guitarist,<ref name="Ed" /> but was replaced by George Vjestica for the European leg of the tour; Vjestica's 12-string guitar-playing was featured on several ''Push the Sky Away'' tracks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds|url=http://www.georgevjestica.com/#!news/cdmj|work=George Vjestica|publisher=George Vjestica|access-date=24 August 2013|date=25 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ASTRAL TRAVELLING|url=http://www.themonthly.com.au/issue/2013/february/1360534931/mark-mordue/astral-travelling|work=The Monthly|publisher=The Monthly|access-date=24 August 2013|author=Mark Mordue|date=February 2013}}</ref>

During the Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds summer USA tour in 2013 a smaller incarnation of the band recorded [[Live from KCRW]] (Cave, Ellis, Casey, Sclavunos and Adamson). In 2014 Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds toured North America with Ellis, Adamson, Sclavunos, Casey plus Conway Savage and George Vjestica. Cave embarked on solo tours in Australia and New Zealand in late 2014 and Europe in 2015 with Adamson on keyboards and percussion, joined by the rhythm section of Wydler and Casey, and with Ellis as the featured multi-instrumentalist. 
In May 2015, Toby Dammit replaced Adamson as a guest touring member; Adamson has not returned since, and Dammit did not participate in sessions for the subsequent Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds album.

On 2 June 2016, the official Nick Cave website announced a documentary film titled ''[[One More Time with Feeling]]'' (directed by [[Andrew Dominik]]) which was screened on 8 September 2016. It accompanies the band's 16th album titled ''[[Skeleton Tree]]'' (released 9 September 2016). In 2017, Cave begun writing songs for the next Bad Seeds record, which is set to complete a musical trilogy the band began with ''[[Push the Sky Away]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/may/04/nick-cave-death-son-struggle-write-tragedy|title=Nick Cave: 'I have turned a corner and wandered on to a vast landscape'|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|last=Mordue|first=Mark|date=5 May 2017|access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref> Ellis and Cave played two orchestral shows at Hamer Hall in Melbourne, Australia on 9 and 10 August, featuring a selection of their various film scores.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://consequenceofsound.net/2019/04/nick-cave-and-warren-ellis-orchestral-shows/|title=Nick Cave and Warren Ellis announce orchestral shows|website=Consequenceofsound.com|date=10 April 2019}}</ref>

On 23 September 2019, Cave formally announced the album ''[[Ghosteen]]'', to be released at the beginning of October 2019.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/nick-cave-new-album-ghosteen-888656/|title=Nick Cave Confirms New Album 'Ghosteen' is Coming 'Next Week'|last1=Zemler|first1=Emily|date=2019-09-23|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-23}}</ref> It premiered on Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds' [[YouTube]] channel on 3 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GwlU_wsT20Q|title=Ghosteen – Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds (Global Premiere)|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref>

On 22 October 2021, the band released ''[[B-Sides & Rarities Part II]]''; the sequel to their 2005 compilation ''B-Sides & Rarities''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://store.nickcave.com/products/b-sides-rarities-part-ii|title=B-Sides & Rarities (Part II)}}</ref> In June 2022, the band embarked upon their first tour since the onset of [[COVID-19]], with their 2020 ''Ghosteen'' tour having previously been cancelled due to the pandemic. For the tour, the band were joined by four additional members – keyboardist [[Carly Paradis]] and backing vocalists Janet Ramus, T Jae Cole, and Subrina McCalla – alongside returning touring keyboardist Larry Mullins.
